awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Dimers in Combinatorics and Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
Statistical mechanics is the mathematical study of matter at small scales.  Its primary goals are to analyze phase transitions: for example liquid-to-solid transitions where the physical properties of a substance change abruptly.  The dimer model was originally conceived as a simplified model of two-dimensional matter in which phase transitions can be studied. Recent work, however, has linked the model to many other areas of mathematics, from combinatorics to string theory, where ''brane dimers'' are proposed as fundamental descriptions of spacetime at small scales.  The PIs propose to jointly investigate a number of interrelated topics in mathematics and physics, each of which has the dimer model as its underlying combinatorial structure. This project will lead to the organization of workshops and regular meetings of the PIs and their graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, continuing the PIs' efforts to get young mathematicians and physicists involved in these topics.  The PIs will contribute to the mathematical community through their mentorship of young scholars, research talks in conferences and workshops, papers published in peer-reviewed journals, and books on a selection of these topics.

The dimer model studies the set of all dimers, or perfect matchings, on a planar bipartite graph G on a disk or Riemann surface. Despite the simple definition, there are many open problems about the dimer model, as well as applications to geometry, algebra, and physics. There is a fundamental connection between the dimer model on the disk and the Grassmannian, via the fact that generating functions of dimers satisfy Plucker relations. This fact leads to the cluster algebra structure on the homogeneous coordinate ring of the Grassmannian, and the beautiful combinatorics of the positive Grassmannian.  This project will explore a myriad of generalizations of the objects mentioned above, and will significantly improve our understanding of: the dimer model on non-planar graphs; limiting behaviors of the dimer model on a torus and other surfaces; the connection between dimers on a torus and brane tilings in string theory; soliton solutions to the KP equation and the bipartite graphs realizable as soliton graphs; the relationship between convex polygon tilings and the corresponding bipartite planar graphs with Kasteleyn weightings; the connection between the dimer model and triangulations of the amplituhedron, an object whose volume computes scattering amplitudes; and higher-dimensional dimer models, colored quivers and a generalized notion of cluster mutation, exciting new objects motivated by dualities in supersymmetric quantum field theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to study a variety of questions coming from combinatorics and physics, including the amplituhedron, cluster algebras, and statistical physics.

The PI together with physicists Tomasz Lukowski and Matteo Parisi completed a paper ``The positive tropical Grassmannian, the hypersimplex, and the m=2 amplituhedron,"  which made a surprising conjecture (with proofs in some cases)  linking the positive tropical Grassmannian and the m=2 amplituhedron, a geometric object connected to scattering amplitudes.  This paper was published in International Mathematics Research Notices.

The above work lead to the PI's paper ``The positive Dressian equals the positive tropical Grassmannian,'' with David Speyer, which recently  appeared in Transactions of the American Mathematical Society.  This paper proved the theorem stated in the title, and gave a new ``tropical" proof of da Silva's 1987 conjecture, that positively oriented matroids are realizable.

The paper with Lukowski and Parisi also led to  a joint paper of the PI together with   Melissa Sherman-Bennett and  Parisi called  ``The m=2 amplituhedron and the hypersimplex: signs, clusters, triangulations, Eulerian numbers,'' which   proved the sign-flip conjecture of Arkani-Hamed--Thomas--Trnka for the m=2 amplituhedron.  The authors   also demonstrated a cluster algebra structure in the $m=2$ amplituhedron, and proved the striking T-duality conjecture of Lukowski--Parisi--Williams: that positroid tilings of the hypersimplex (induced by the moment map) are in bijection with positroid tilings of the m=2 amplituhedron (induced by the amplituhedron map).  This paper was recently accepted to Communications of the AMS.

The PI together with Robert Moerman wrote a paper ``Grass trees and forests: enumeration of Grass(mannian) trees and forests, with applications to the momentum amplituhedron,'' which gives the rank generating function for contracted plabic forests. These objects conjecturally correspond to cells in a cell decomposition of the momentum amplituhedron.  Along the way the authors also provided an exponential-formula-style result for enumerating trees and forests whose vertices are decorated by an auxiliary function, and the authors applied their results to enumerate separable permutations.  This paper was recently accepted to Combinatorial Theory.

The PI together with  Donghyun Kim studied the inhomogeneous multispecies exclusion process on a ring, in which particles of different species hop on a circle, with rates depending on their species.  The authors showed that the steady state probability of each  ``evil-avoiding'' state is proportional to a product of Schubert polynomials.  This paper recently appeared in International Mathematics Research Notices.

The PI together with Jon Boretsky and Chris Eur wrote a paper ``Polyhedral and tropical geometry of flag positroids,'' currently submitted, which studies flag positroids whose set of ranks is a sequence of consecutive numbers.  In this case the authors showed that the nonnegative tropical flag variety equals the nonnegative flag Dresssian, and that points of these spaces give rise to coherent subdivisions of flag positroid polytopes.  As a corollary, this paper shows that every positively oriented flag matroid of consecutive ranks is realizable.

Additionally, the PI wrote two survey papers.  The first survey paper is ``The positive Grassmannian, the amplituhedron, and cluster algebras,'' and was for the Proceedings of the 2022 International Congress of Mathematics.  The second survey paper is ``The combinatorics of hopping particles and positivity in Markov chains,'' and is to celebrate the 500th issue of the London Mathematical Society Newsletter.

The PI has been working  on her book Introduction to Cluster algebras with Sergey Fomin and Andrei Zelevinsky.  The authors finished two chapters, Chapters  6 and 7.   While most of the book is expository, Chapter 6  includes a new result,  a presentation of any finitely-generated cluster algebra as a polynomial ring modulo the saturation of the exchange ideal.

Over the period of the grant, the PI and the other members of the FRG team met periodically over zoom to discuss their research projects and plan activities.   They held an online workshop in August 2020, and will hold a summer school and workshop in August 2023.

The PI currently has six graduate students: Jonathan Boretsky, Jiyang (Johnny) Gao, Yuhan (Michelle) Jiang, Grant Barkley, Amanda Burcroff, and Victor Wang.  In 2021 the PI graduated three PhD students: Melissa Sherman-Bennett, Donghyun Kim, and Mario Sanchez, and in 2023 the PI graduated PhD student Charles Wang.

The PI mentored five undergraduates at Harvard: Hanna Mularczyk, Fan Zhou,  Amal Mattoo, Anne Larsen, and Raluca Vlad.

Finally, the PI has been a mentor for the following  postdoctoral fellows: Elana Kalashnikov, Mandy Cheung, Cesar Cuenca, Christian Gaetz, Anna Seigal, Christopher Eur, Matteo Parisi, and Colin Defant.
